posts.cooked:
There have been multiple requests that revolve around profile sharing controls, and while they are all slightly different, they have a significant amount of overlap and result in duplicate discussions. Due to the timespan of the threads and related discussion, rather than a confusing merge of all the posts, I am simply going to close the other topics and link them here. Any discussion relating to profile sharing can be continued in this topic.

More control over who can see my profile photo Feature Requests
I would like to set PRIVACY ON PHOTO PROFILE, so I can decide that is not visible to people I don‚Äôt have in my contacts, or be visibile to just some of my contacts.
Ability to see if you have shared your profile with someone or not Android Feature Requests
On Signal iOS it is already possible to see whether you have made your profile visible to someone. On Android this is not possible yet. An important principle of privacy is that you can know who has your information. It isn‚Äôt essential, but it is certainly nice to have. On a sidenote: I don‚Äôt like the phrase ‚Äúshared your profile‚Äù to me it sounds better if it says ‚Äúmade your profile visible to‚Äù because that is less abstract and thus easier to comprehend.
Do not force user to reveal their profile picture and name to others (do not make sharing profile mandatory) Feature Requests
We recently had a discussion on this forum about the fact that filling out a first name is mandatory. Some commenters mentioned that it isn‚Äôt such a big deal if you are required to fill out your first name, partly because they still control who they reveal it to. There are however signs that Signal-devs are planning to make sharing profile mandatory. That means that whoever you chat with will get to see your profile name and picture. This might also mean that if a stranger reaches out to you, a‚Ä¶
Do not keep sharing every new profile name and profile picture I set with people I no longer chat with Feature Requests
How long does Signal keep sharing every new profile photo I set with contacts who I once chatted with? I am concerned that a large number of people who I used to once chat with or be in a group with (potentially hundreds of people) can keep looking at and potentially save every new profile name I set and every new profile photo I set. It is very unpractical to block all contacts who I no longer chat with, especially if I deleted the conversation and can‚Äôt view the option to block them anymore. ‚Ä¶
Ability to stop sharing your profile with people Feature Requests
Stop sharing means: they will keep seeing the profile picture and name which you were using the moment you stopped sharing - they won‚Äôt receive updates of your profile name, status or picture. As it stands today anyone you were once in a group with will keep seeing every new pucture you set for yourself, but you have no idea who or how many people are seeing your new profile picture. We need two things: an overview of people who we are sharing our profile with a way to stop sharing the profi‚Ä¶

link_counts.title: Do not force user to reveal their profile picture and name to others (do not make sharing profile mandatory)
Do not keep sharing every new profile name and profile picture I set with people I no longer chat with
Ability to stop sharing your profile with people
More control over who can see my profile photo
Ability to see if you have shared your profile with someone or not
Do not force user to reveal their profile picture and name to others (do not make sharing profile mandatory)
Ability to see if you have shared your profile with someone or not
More control over who can see my profile photo
Ability to stop sharing your profile with people
Privacy mode plsss
Group privacy settings - unknown members
Why no Privacy settings for Profile Picture & About?
Untrusted groups/contact and profile visibility
How can Signal be better for communities and organisers?
Screenshot / recording detection and/or blocking
Usernames in Signal
Can users in a group automatically message me without message request?
Do not keep sharing every new profile name and profile picture I set with people I no longer chat with

posts.cooked:
Everytime I change my profile name both old AND new name is visible for everybody ‚Äì what the heck?! This is really a privacy leck at Signal or kinda bug, I don‚Äôt get why it‚Äôs not solved. Even Whatsapp doesn‚Äôt have such a privacy breach like this. And yea, I wanna control who can see my profile pic, too.

signal-2021-09-30-111250_0011600√ó1600 105 KB

That string is there to let others know who is whom. Without that, people could change profile data all the time and it would be difficult to keep track.

Ideally, Signal should provide control over what you show to others so that you can manage what/how you want to be seen and it should build in contact management inside the app so that people can also manage how they want to see their contacts.

There is no solution for the former and the latter requires leaking data to the system. In the future, with usernames and phone# non-sharing, it might not even be possible.
My phone number should be more than enough to show who I am. I‚Äôm not against profile names, but it‚Äôs absolutely not necessary to show all Signal contacts changing of names.
Phone number can be hidden in the future. There might be nothing user visible other than profile data. (UUIDs are hidden)

Cologne:

This is really a privacy leck at Signal or kinda bug

No it isn‚Äôt. Your previous profile name was already visible and known to everyone you had shared your profile with, and when you change it, it is still visible to those same people ‚Äì no information is being ‚Äúleaked‚Äù and it is an intentional design and not a bug.

The notification is so that people are aware you changed your name and don‚Äôt accidentally send a sensitive message to the wrong person ‚Äì maybe you changed your name to ‚ÄúBob‚Äù and used one of the default built-in avatars as your profile image, but I already have another contact named Bob who also happened to use the same profile image. I might open the conversation with you, thinking that it was the ‚Äúreal‚Äù Bob, and send something that shouldn‚Äôt be sent to you. The notification helps to make me aware of who I am sending a message to.

Example

Add warning when someone names themselves "Note to Self" and uses the note to self profile picture Feature Requests
I just discovered one of the people I were in a group with is actually doing this. If I search ‚Äúnote to self‚Äù on Desktop his chat shows up and the real note to self does not. This is a security / social engineering risk. The app could hardcode a warning when the name matches with or closely matches with note to self. For translations this might be a lot more difficult to do however.

link_counts.title: Add warning when someone names themselves "Note to Self" and uses the note to self profile picture

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
Signal really took a step back in terms of privacy when they made pdofile sharing automatic and mandatory. Anyone you were on e in a group with gets your latest profile picture, and meanwhild you can‚Äôt even see who can see you.

This feature WhatsApp is adding gives you more control than Signal‚Äôs ‚Äòno control at all‚Äô. However what WhatsApp is adding there is still not good enough, you can only prevent people who you manually add to that list from seeing your prodile picture, but you will easily still be sharing your profile picture with hundreds of group members from all kinds of groups you are a member of, without even knowing it.

What I would want for Signal is that we can set multiple profiles, (one for family members, one for your kinky friend group, one for coworkers) and choose per contact which profile that person gets to see. That way I can boast to my kinky friends about how tight the leather fits around my thighs while my family sees regular me between some trees in the park, and coworkers see my professional photo‚Äôs of me in my best suit.

Note that there is one thing Signal does better than WhatsApp: Signal doesn‚Äôg hide your profile after it has already been shown. If you block someone on Signal, they can‚Äôt twll they have been blocked, they just never see youf profile picture change. On WhatsApp your picture disappears, which is hurtful, unnatural, and receals that you blocked them. It feels like your menory of someone gets deleted from your own device. I hate it. There is no point in doing that. The oicture had beeen seen already anyway so deleting it doesn‚Äôt acomplish anything but set bad blood. I hope Signal never changes their approach to blocked contacts still seeing the picture you had at the time they got blocked.

Who can see my Signal Profile? It is automatically shared with any contacts you have saved in your address book

Just because I have a phone number in my contacts, this does not mean I want whomever owns that phone number to know my name and whatever other personal information is in my profile. Can we get a way to turn off this form of profile sharing, such that it‚Äôs only shared once conversations are initiated?

I‚Äôd love to use the profile feature for only my friends. Currently, I have my first name set to ‚Äú.‚Äù with the rest of my profile blank because I‚Äôm not comfortable making it public.

Some apps, like YouMail, record every number which calls your phone into its own address book. It also makes use of the address book functionality in android, revealing the address book to other apps. If you install Signal on the same device, all someone has to do is call you to see your Signal profile. It would be great if we could prevent private data leaking between Signal and other apps in this way.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
By reading the strings recently added to the Signal Android project you can see that Signal introduces a new term: ‚ÄòSignal connections‚Äô.

Your connections can see your name and photo, and can see posts to ‚ÄúMy Story‚Äù unless you hide it from them.

Adding content to your story allows your Signal connections to view it for 24 hours. You can change who can view your story in Settings.

By default everything you do on Signal is visible to those Signal connections. Another string explains what Signal Connections are exactly:

Signal Connections are people you‚Äôve chosen to trust, either by:

  • Starting a conversation
  • Accepting a message request
  • Having them in your system contacts

So basically anyone you once had any conversation with. One thing that is not made obvious here whether ‚Äúaccepting a message request‚Äù includes joining a group, and thus whether anyone who is in that group is also one of your Signal Connections.

Either way,
I personally find this a very strange concept of ‚Äòtrust‚Äô. Just one message or polite reply to someone and they can see your profile and your stories and any updates indefinitely. This to me is a violation of my privacy and free choice.

The strings do mention that you have a few settings to exclude some people, but the assumption that I want to share my stories and new profile picture with someone who I once chatted with feels like something I never consented to, and now I have to manually opt-out. In fact the strings do not yet show that users will get any control over excluding who you share you current and future profile pictures with, the only way to do that is by fully blocking someone. take for example your boss: you don‚Äôt need that guy to get your new profile picture, but you also don‚Äôt want to block him. You can exclude people from seeing your stories, however you may have to include them one by one and each time you upload a story.

In my option we need to think about what Signal Connections should be. Maybe they should expire after a certain amount of no contact. Maybe I should be able to manually remove people from the list of ‚ÄúSignal Connections‚Äù.

Meteor0id:

whether anyone who is in that group is also one of your Signal Connections.

If you‚Äôre asking whether stories are sent to them by default, then no. I believe Signal Connections are exactly those who appear after you hit the blue pencil button. It is somewhat ridiculous for Signal to decide that people ‚Äúchose to trust‚Äù someone with something when they never knew that they were doing it.

BTW, the issue with sending stories out to all those people is something I‚Äôve pointed out in the stories thread but who knows whether anyone deciding stuff reads any of it. Maybe more people will point it out when this actually shows up in a beta.

Meteor0id:

the only way to do that is by fully blocking someone.

If you block and unblock someone who is not in any common group, you‚Äôll rotate the profile key. The new key is immediately uploaded to every group where you‚Äôre a member but not to everyone you‚Äôve chatted with. So people who aren‚Äôt interacting with you anymore won‚Äôt see changes in your profile.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
newuser:

people who aren‚Äôt interacting with you anymore

How long is ‚Äòanymore‚Äô? And does opening the chat or typing something but not sending it also count as ‚Äòinteracting‚Äô? In other words, can they trigger the update from their side without actions from me?

newuser:

It is somewhat ridiculous for Signal to decide that people ‚Äúchose to trust‚Äù someone with something when they never knew that they were doing it.

Exactly

newuser:

who knows whether anyone deciding stuff reads any of it

Wouldn‚Äôt it be nice if they started seeing the relevance of replying to us and showing that they feel responsible for the way they design these features and how it impacts privacy between users.

newuser:

If you block and unblock someone

I don‚Äôt know about you but I do this on average once every five years I guess. So that‚Äôs no use.

newuser:

If you‚Äôre asking whether stories are sent to them by default, then no. I believe Signal Connections are exactly those who appear after you hit the blue pencil button.

So group members are not Signal Connections, even though they do get my profile key? That would make sense however I still wish that would be confirmed in the text string which explains what Signal Connections are.

They would have to send you a message. Then your client sees that a non sealed sender message was sent but profilesharing=true and so it sends the new profile key.

So just opening the chat wouldn‚Äôt work but I am not sure about call initiation/typing indicators.

If you are an internal user, you can disable these kind of leaks.

Meteor0id:

I don‚Äôt know about you but I do this on average once every five years I guess. So that‚Äôs no use.

It is just a way to rotate the profile key without using an internal user feature. The only effect is what I said. Contacts not sharing groups will have a stale profile key until there is some interaction.

Meteor0id:

So group members are not Signal Connections, even though they do get my profile key? That would make sense however I still wish that would be confirmed in the text string which explains what Signal Connections are.

Yes. It would have been simple to just say that they are those that appear in the contact list but I guess they wanted to inform somehow that people are trusting others with something. The better way to do this is to inform people when they‚Äôre taking those actions: accepting message request, added a new system contact who is using Signal, initiating a chat.

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
newuser:

The better way to do this is to inform people when they‚Äôre taking those actions: accepting message request, added a new system contact who is using Signal, initiating a chat.

Totally agree, but Signal is not doing that today. And as of right now they say completely nothing about what other group members can see.

newuser:

They would have to send you a message. Then your client sees that a non sealed sender message was sent but profilesharing=true and so it sends the new profile key.

And so anyone who wants to stalk me and see every profile picture I upload can do so, even if I block and unblock someone every week just to cycle my profile key.
I don‚Äôt think Signal is offering much privacy here.
Unfortunately, yes, running your own build is somewhat necessary because Signal deliberately cripples the app in many ways.
